description: From Middle English sluse, alteration of scluse, from Anglo-Norman escluse (“sluice, floodgate”), from Late Latin exclusa (“extrusion, gate”), from Latin exclūsus, form of exclūdō (“I shut out, I exclude”) (English exclude). Cognate to Dutch sluis.

entries.meaning: An artificial passage for water, fitted with a valve or gate, for example in a canal lock or a mill stream, for stopping or regulating the flow.
Hence, an opening or channel through which anything flows; a source of supply.
examples: Each sluice of affluent fortune open'd soon.

entries.meaning: The stream flowing through a floodgate.
(mining) A long box or trough through which water flows, used for washing auriferous earth.
(linguistics) An instance of wh-stranding ellipsis, or sluicing.

verbs.description: sluice (third-person singular simple present sluices, present participle sluicing, simple past and past participle sluiced)

entries.meaning: (transitive, rare) To emit by, or as by, flood gates.
(transitive) To wet copiously, as by opening a sluice
examples: Nine - mile Creek has been dug out again and again , and has been sluiced three times

entries.meaning: (transitive) To wash with, or in, a stream of water running through a sluice.
examples: to sluice earth or gold dust in a sluice box in placer mining

entries.meaning: (transitive, more generally) To wash (down or out).
examples: And now men with a hose have come and are sluicing out the streets.
In the trough behind the white wave / Helen shook her dark head, the water sluiced from her shoulders / And rose-tipped breasts.

entries.meaning: (linguistics) To elide the complement in a coordinated wh-question. See sluicing.
